English 9.description: Students will actively listen using agreed-upon discussion rules with control of verbal and nonverbal cues.
Students will actively listen in order to analyze and evaluate speakers' verbal and nonverbal messages by asking questions to clarify purpose and perspective.

Students will work effectively and respectfully in diverse groups by showing willingness to make necessary compromises to accomplish a goal, sharing responsibility for collaborative work, and recognizing individual contributions.

Students will follow agreed-upon rules as they engage in collaborative discussions about what they are reading and writing, expressing their own ideas clearly, building on the ideas of others, and respectfully disagreeing when necessary.
Students will conduct formal and informal presentations in a variety of contexts supporting their message with evidence and using verbal and nonverbal cues.
Students will summarize the main ideas and paraphrase significant parts of increasingly complex texts.
Students will identify characteristics of genres and analyze how they enhance comprehension of fiction, poetry, drama, and nonfiction.
Students will routinely and recursively prewrite (e.g., develop and organize ideas).
Students will routinely and recursively develop drafts, applying organizational structure(s) (e.g., description, compare/contrast, sequential, problem/solution, cause/effect).
Students will routinely and recursively revise drafts for organization, transitions, sentence variety, and consistent tone and point of view in order to improve coherence and meaning.
Students will routinely and recursively use resources to edit for grammar, usage, mechanics, and format in order to finalize drafts for publication.
Students will routinely and recursively publish final drafts for an authentic audience.
Students will analyze the extent to which historical, cultural, and/or global perspectives affect authors' stylistic choices in grade-level literary and informational texts.
Students will evaluate authors' perspectives and explain how those perspectives contribute to the meanings of texts.
Students will evaluate how literary elements impact theme, mood, and/or tone, using textual evidence: setting, plot structure, conflict, characters, characterization, point of view, archetypes.

Students will evaluate how literary devices impact theme, mood, and/or tone: figurative language (simile, metaphor, personification, hyperbole, imagery, symbolism), sound devices (onomatopoeia, alliteration, assonance), irony (verbal, situational, dramatic).

Students will evaluate the validity of a speaker's argument: distinguish kinds of evidence, distinguish substantiated from unsubstantiated claims, analyze rhetorical appeals (ethos, logos, pathos), identify bias, identify logical fallacies.
Students will analyze how informational text structures support the author's purpose.
Students will analyze how two or more texts address similar themes or topics, using textual evidence to support their claims and inferences.

Students will compose narratives reflecting real or imagined experiences with engaging plots, complex characters, intentional sequencing, precise language, sensory details, dialogue, and varied syntax.

Students will compose informative essays, reports, or technical writing that objectively introduce topics, include a defensible thesis, incorporate evidence, maintain organized structure, and establish a formal style.
Students will compose argumentative essays with precise claims, defensible thesis, counterclaims, logical organization, credible sources, and appropriate style and tone.
Students will blend narrative, informative, and argumentative writing to suit their audience and purpose.
Students will analyze the relationships among synonyms, antonyms, and analogies.
Students will use context clues, connotation, and denotation to determine or clarify the meaning of words or distinguish among multiple-meaning words.
Students will use word parts (e.g., affixes, Anglo-Saxon, Greek, and Latin roots, stems) to define and determine the meaning of increasingly complex words.
Students will use resources (e.g., dictionary, glossary, thesaurus) to determine or clarify meanings, syllabication, pronunciation, synonyms, parts of speech, and etymology.
Students will use precise, grade-level vocabulary in writing to clearly communicate complex ideas.
Students will select language to create a specific effect in writing according to purpose and audience.
Students will recognize and examine the effect of parallel structure and active and passive voice to convey specific meanings.
Students will recognize noun, verb, adjectival, and adverbial phrases and explain their effect in particular sentences.
Students will use or revise for active/passive voice and parallel structure in words and phrases for effect.
Students will add clarity, variety, and/or style to their writing with parts of speech and various types of phrases and clauses.
Students will recognize and correct misplaced and dangling modifiers.
Students will write using correct capitalization mechanics.
Students will write using correct end mark mechanics.
Students will write using correct apostrophe mechanics.
Students will use commas to set off simple parenthetical elements.
Students will use a colon to reveal information.
Students will use an ellipsis to indicate omission from quoted material and brackets to indicate an addition or clarification to quoted material.
Students will write using correct italics mechanics.
Students will write using correct semicolon mechanics.
Students will find and comprehend information about a topic, using their own viable research questions.
Students will synthesize relevant information from a variety of primary and secondary sources, following ethical and legal citation guidelines.
Students will evaluate the relevance, reliability, and validity of the information gathered.
Students will formulate and refine a viable research question.
Students will develop a clear, concise, defensible thesis statement.
Students will integrate quotes, paraphrases, and summaries from research, following a consistent citation style to avoid plagiarism.
Students will present research in longer and shorter formats to a variety of audiences.
Students will analyze and evaluate the techniques used in a variety of multimodal content and how they contribute to meaning.
Students will create engaging multimodal content that intentionally addresses an audience and accomplishes a purpose.
Students will select texts for specific purposes and read independently for extended periods of time.
Students will write independently using print, cursive, and/or typing for various lengths of time, intentionally selecting and combining modes and genres.

French 1 (World Languages - Novice).description: I can identify memorized or familiar words when they are supported by modified input, gestures, or visuals when heard or viewed within texts.
I can identify some basic facts from memorized or familiar words and phrases when heard or viewed within texts; these may be supported by modified input, gestures, or visuals.
I can identify the topic, some details, and/or familiar questions from simple sentences when heard, signed, or viewed within texts.
I can identify memorized or familiar words when they are supported by modified input, gestures, or visuals when read within texts.
I can identify some basic facts from memorized or familiar words and phrases when viewed or read within texts.
I can identify the topic, some details, and/or familiar questions from simple sentences when read within texts. I can sometimes understand the main idea of what I have read.
I can communicate about very familiar topics using a variety of words and phrases that I have practiced and memorized to share information, reactions, opinions, and feelings.
I can request and provide information about very familiar topics using a variety of words and phrases that I have practiced and memorized.
I can request and provide information about very familiar topics using a variety of words and phrases that I have practiced and memorized, as well as explore opportunities for future career paths.

I can present information about myself and other very familiar topics of immediate interest in highly predictable settings using single words, memorized phrases, or signs relying upon repetition, visual aids, and gestures.
I can present information about myself and other very familiar topics of immediate interest using a variety of words or phrases, relying upon repetition, visual aids, and gestures.
I can present basic information on familiar topics that relate to me in a variety of settings, sometimes relying upon clarification and circumlocution, using phrases and simple sentences.

I can present information about myself and other very familiar topics using single words or memorized phrases, relying on visual aids. I can reproduce some familiar words, characters, or phrases in culturally accepted ways.

I can present information about myself and some other very familiar topics using a variety of words, phrases, and memorized expressions, often relying upon visual aids. I can write lists and memorized phrases on familiar topics.

I can present basic information on familiar topics that relate to me in a variety of settings, sometimes relying upon clarification and circumlocution, using phrases and simple sentences. I can compose short messages and notes on familiar topics.

French 1 (World Languages - Novice).category: Relating Cultural Practices to Perspectives - Novice
French 1 (World Languages - Novice).description: I can imitate patterns of behavior in formal and informal settings, identify and participate in traditional practices and cultural activities, identify with some perspectives and worldviews, recognize diversity and the impact of stereotyping, and recognize differences and similarities between target cultures and my own.

French 1 (World Languages - Novice).category: Relating Cultural Products to Perspectives - Novice
French 1 (World Languages - Novice).description: I can identify and explore artifacts, symbols, major contributions, influential figures, historical and contemporary influences, products, geographic features, and cultural perspectives from the arts and media in the target cultures.

I can identify and/or apply selected information and skills from other content areas in experiences related to the target language and cultures. I can reinforce and/or expand learning in other content areas using authentic target-language resources.

I can extract information about the target cultures from selected authentic sources and use authentic target-language sources to gain insight about the distinctive perspectives of the target language.
I can identify cognates and borrowed words, identify similarities and differences in sound and writing systems, make comparisons of basic language forms, and compare basic idiomatic expressions.

I can identify similarities and differences in verbal and nonverbal behavior between cultures, recognize and analyze intercultural similarities and differences in practices, products, and perspectives, and explore how generalized perceptions shape identity and culture.

I can demonstrate a willingness to interact with native speakers, practice oral or written use of the target language outside academic settings, communicate on a personal level, and produce short presentations for a variety of audiences.

I can identify career paths enhanced by proficiency in another language, discover and explore entertainment sources and samples of art, literature, or music representative of the target cultures, and identify current topics or events of interest.
